critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final target image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Absence of charts or graphs is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification if no charts or graphs are present.
When in doubt, do NOT classify an element as a chart or graph. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify regular images or simple illustrations as charts or graphs, unless they represent data in a structured, visual format.
Charts and graphs must contain visual elements that convey numerical or statistical information.

charts_graphs_definition.item: A chart or graph is a visual representation of data or statistical information.
Charts and graphs typically use axes, data points, bars, lines, or areas to represent numerical relationships.
Charts and graphs should have clear labels, scales, and often a legend explaining the data representation.
Text in charts and graphs is typically used for labels, titles, and data values.

category.name: cartesian
category.description: Charts with X and Y axes
category.types: bar chart, line graph, scatter plot, area chart, histogram, box plot, candlestick, waterfall
category.output_structure: Use x_axis, y_axis, and data_series with x/y points

category.name: proportional
category.description: Charts showing parts of a whole
category.types: pie chart, donut chart, treemap, sunburst, waffle chart
category.output_structure: Use segments with label, value, percentage - NO x/y axes

category.name: flow
category.description: Charts showing movement or relationships between entities
category.types: sankey diagram, alluvial diagram, chord diagram, network graph
category.output_structure: Use nodes (with position: left/middle/right) and flows (source, target, value)

category.name: composite
category.types: grid of charts, faceted plots, small multiples, subplot arrangements
category.output_structure: Use layout description and sub_charts array with panel_id (a), (b), etc.

category.name: matrix
category.types: heatmap, correlation matrix, confusion matrix, calendar heatmap
category.output_structure: Use row_labels, column_labels, cells with row/column/value, and color_scale

category.name: radar
category.types: radar chart, spider chart, polar chart
category.output_structure: Use axes list and data_series with axis/amount pairs

figure_reference_guidance.item: ALWAYS capture the figure caption exactly as written (e.g., "Figure 5. Cost overruns for...")
Look for text on the page that references this figure (e.g., "as shown in Figure 5", "see Fig. 3")
The caption often appears directly below or above the chart
For multi-panel figures, note sub-labels like (a), (b), (A), (B) in both the figure and caption

not_charts_graphs.item: Photographs or realistic illustrations without data representation are NOT charts or graphs.
Simple sketches or doodles without clear data content are NOT charts or graphs.
Tables of text or data without graphical representation are NOT charts or graphs.
Decorative graphics or borders are NOT charts or graphs.
Diagrams or flowcharts that don't primarily represent numerical data are NOT considered charts or graphs.

decision_process.item: Follow the two-step verification process defined in the charts_graphs_verification_process.xml file.
In the first pass, identify all potential chart-like or graph-like structures.
In the second pass, rigorously verify each potential chart or graph against the defined criteria.
Consider the context around each potential chart or graph to avoid misclassification.
For verified charts and graphs, ensure you capture the key elements, data representation, and overall structure.
